text_image_relationship.layout_style: Full‐page miniature framed by three Gothic trefoil arches; the image occupies nearly the entire folio, with a narrow gold frame and minimal margins. No running text; only the INRI titulus above Christ’s head interrupts the pictorial field.

text_content.script_style: Gothic display capitals (lapidary majuscules) on painted titulus panel

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf reserved for divine context (halo, frame, background pattern). Ultramarine blue forms a deep star‐dappled field, signifying the heavenly realm. Red drapery echoes the blood of martyrdom. Layered application with white highlighting on drapery folds and flesh tones. The strong contrast between warm reds and cool blues directs focus to the central figure. Original pigments remain vibrant with minimal lead‐white darkening.

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill‐pen outlines in dark brown ink with bold contours and fine internal detail
drawing_technique.shading_method: Minimal parallel hatching; flat color fields with white highlights to model drapery and flesh
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling of Christ larger than flanking figures; overlapping to indicate spatial order without true linear perspective

content_theme.scene_description: Primary Scene Analysis: The single crucifixion scene shows five figures arranged on a shallow stage of earth. Christ occupies center on a tall black cross, his body slumped, head crowned with a gold cruciform halo. To Christ’s left stands the impenitent thief on a shorter cross; to his right, the penitent thief. At left foreground, a Roman soldier (Longinus) in a red tunic, pointed hat and black hose thrusts a spear into Christ’s side. Spatial Organization: The three crosses form a horizontal axis set against a deep blue, gold-dotted field framed by Gothic arches. Christ is largest, central and elevated; flanks recede slightly to create shallow depth. Costume and Equipment Details: Longinus wears a red, pleated tunic with white inner highlights, leather belt and black hose. The two thieves wear simple red loincloths with white highlighting. Crosses are rendered in solid black. Secondary Elements: The blue field is patterned with punched gold diaper; the folio border is burnished gold leaf. Architectural framing uses red panels with gold quatrefoils. Symbolic Components: The INRI titulus above Christ’s head and cruciform halo identify him as Messiah and King of the Jews. Halo rays and gold frame underscore divine presence. Compositional Focus: All visual weight centers on Christ’s nailed hands and feet, accentuated by red blood drops and the dynamic diagonal of the spear, while the symmetrical thieves reinforce the central axis.

secondary_functions: Aide‐memoire for meditation on Christ’s Passion

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This mid-13th-century Parisian illumination, likely from a private Book of Hours, exemplifies the era’s affective devotional program. The opulent use of ultramarine and burnished gold leaf, coupled with a deep, star-dappled field, situates the Passion within a heavenly realm tailored for individual meditation. The Gothic trefoil arches and punched diaper pattern reflect a sophisticated Parisian workshop tradition influenced by the Court School; multiple hands are suggested by slight variations in drapery treatment between figures. Technically, the raised gesso underlay and fine quill outlines demonstrate advanced layering and underdrawing practices, while the hierarchical scaling and absence of true perspective adhere to established iconographic conventions. Iconographically, the cruciform halo and INRI titulus underscore theological emphasis on Christ’s kingship and sacrificial role. The soldier’s dynamic spear thrust introduces a dramatic gesture contrasting with the static, symmetrical thieves, heightening emotional engagement. Comparing this miniature to the Psalter of Blanche of Castile reveals shared compositional frameworks and color palettes, yet here a greater expressiveness in Christ’s anguished visage foreshadows later Gothic innovations. Thus, the illumination bridges traditional typological representation and emerging Gothic naturalism, serving both as a devotional focus and a statement of aristocratic taste in the 1250s Parisian milieu.
